The new rules aim to ‚Äúonly affect less than 5% of users,‚Äù but have ignited the developer community ‚Äî many ‚Äúfreeloader exploiters‚Äù lament they can no longer harvest GPU computing power.

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

Remember the days of unlimited Claude Code access through ‚Äúshared accounts + automated scripts‚Äù? Those good times are over. Anthropic sent emails to subscribers announcing a stricter weekly cap system, with just one reason: fairness + stability.

‚ÄúSome power users run Claude in the background 24 hours a day, even reselling access permissions, slowing everyone down.‚Äù ‚Äî Official email

Section titled ‚Äú1. Account Gray Market Rampant‚Äù

Regular Users

  • Long-running Agents, large single-repository refactoring, parallel multi-instances ‚Äî high probability of hitting limits.

Why Do You Need Claude Code UI?

  • Cross-Device Lightweight Remote Usage: View projects, switch sessions, review changes on iPad/phone, suitable for commuting, meetings, or outdoor scenarios.

The internet era had near-zero marginal costs for ‚Äúinformation flow‚Äù; the AI era has persistently high marginal costs for ‚Äúinformation generation‚Äù that scale linearly with usage.   2. Company Profile: OPEX‚ÜíCAPEX, talent‚ÜíGPU, electricity, data centers, internet companies becoming ‚Äúindustrialized.‚Äù
  3. Personal Strategy: Career shifts from ‚Äúwriting features‚Äù to ‚Äúmanaging engineering and computing economics‚Äù; Assets use ‚ÄúAI upstream leaders + diversified ETFs‚Äù to hedge personal cash flow risk (not investment advice).

Recent Headlines

Section titled ‚ÄúRecent Headlines‚Äù

On July 2, 2025, according to WIRED magazine, Mark Zuckerberg offered top research talent compensation packages worth up to $300 million (approximately 21.8 billion RMB) over four years for his newly established Meta Super Intelligence Lab, with first-year total compensation exceeding $100 million (approximately 727 million RMB).

On July 11, 2025, Nvidia became the world‚Äôs first publicly traded company to exceed $4 trillion in market capitalization. Nvidia spent 30 years building a $1 trillion company, then took just two years to transform into a $4 trillion company.

On July 24, 2025, Google parent company Alphabet announced it would spend $85 billion in capital expenditures in 2025, up from the $75 billion indicated at the beginning of the year.

1. Three Fundamental Differences: PC/Mobile Internet vs. AI Era

‚ë† Information Method: From ‚ÄúInformation Flow‚Äù to ‚ÄúInformation Generation‚Äù

item.title: AI Vibe Coding: Speeding Up or Slowing Down? Insights from a 19% Slowdown
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

This year, AI Vibe Coding programming tools have created quite a buzz in developer circles. Many developers (myself included) thought that with AI intelligent assistants, coding efficiency would dramatically improve. However, recent research threw cold water on us: using AI tools actually slowed development by nearly 19%! This study by METR conducted controlled experiments with experienced open-source developers, yielding surprising results. Participants expected AI to reduce task completion time by 24%, but actually slowed down by nearly one-fifth. More interestingly, even after experiencing the slowdown firsthand, many programmers still believed AI ‚Äúmade me faster‚Äù ‚Äî a kind of ‚Äúpsychological acceleration‚Äù illusion.

As an internet e-commerce backend developer, I actually resonate with these results. Reflecting on my own experience introducing AI assistants for coding, there were indeed many pitfalls: sometimes waiting for AI code output made me scratch my head anxiously, sometimes I had to interrupt my own thinking to accommodate AI. Below, I‚Äôll combine actual development cases to discuss why AI programming might slow down the pace. I hope these experiences can serve as a warning to fellow developers.

The Long Wait for AI Execution

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Long Wait for AI Execution‚Äù

Once upon a time, we coded with brain-to-hand fluidity - when inspiration struck, we‚Äôd tap it out immediately. But after introducing AI assistants, waiting for them to ‚Äúthink‚Äù and output became a new time sink. When implementing asynchronous message processing in my project, I thought I‚Äôd have AI help generate consumer logic. After asking a question, that little circle on screen just kept spinning, with AI ‚Äúpondering‚Äù in the cloud while I could only stare and wait. Those few dozen seconds might seem insignificant, but they accumulate into substantial overhead. More troublesome is when AI occasionally outputs a huge chunk of code at once, forcing me to stop and wait for it to finish scrolling, completely disrupting my rhythm.

During these waiting periods, I‚Äôd unconsciously check emails or do other things, but my mind remained occupied with AI‚Äôs response. In this state, it‚Äôs hard to focus on other tasks, essentially putting me in ‚Äúsuspension‚Äù. Without AI, I might have already coded up an initial draft myself. Now, precious development time slips away waiting for the machine to ‚Äúfinish thinking.‚Äù Clearly, while AI can automatically produce code, its speed doesn‚Äôt necessarily match human intuitive response. The process of waiting for AI is like introducing additional latency into iterations, severely fragmenting what was once a smooth development rhythm.

Disruption from Multitask Switching

Section titled ‚ÄúDisruption from Multitask Switching‚Äù

With AI assistants, I once tried ‚Äúparallel development‚Äù: having AI write one module while I worked on something else. But reality proved that the cost of context switching back and forth was far greater than imagined. For example: when developing idempotency handling for a payment callback interface, I had AI generate code for duplicate request validation while I debugged another piece of business logic. Minutes later, AI produced results, so I switched back to read and integrate. But with the other matter still occupying my mind, I had to shift my thinking to AI‚Äôs code. Going back and forth like this, both sides slowed down.

Humans aren‚Äôt truly adept at multitasking. In work requiring full concentration like coding, frequent context switching creates serious cognitive overhead. Each jump from my own thinking to AI‚Äôs thinking requires time to understand AI‚Äôs code intent and recall the previous problem context. It‚Äôs like listening to two people talk simultaneously - you need to constantly ‚Äúfill in‚Äù context between them, and efficiency suffers accordingly. Especially when AI-generated content differs from my original code style or thinking, I need extra effort to adapt. Imagine developing a complex e-commerce backend feature during peak hours while handling AI ‚Äúinterruptions‚Äù like customer service - this parallelism not only didn‚Äôt save time, but slowed the entire process.

The Burden of Reviewing and Correcting AI Output

Section titled ‚ÄúThe Burden of Reviewing and Correcting AI Output‚Äù

AI-generated code isn‚Äôt ready-to-use; careful review and debugging are often unavoidable. In actual projects, I‚Äôve repeatedly encountered AI ‚Äúhallucinations‚Äù - fabricating non-existent functions or misusing interfaces. For example, what made me both cry and laugh was when I asked AI to help implement idempotency handling for order payment callbacks. It enthusiastically wrote a bunch of code, but closer inspection revealed calls to module functions that didn‚Äôt exist in our system! AI‚Äôs overconfident wild guessing forced me to re-examine every line of code. Research found similar phenomena: developers accepted less than 44% of AI suggestions, with most code requiring modification or rewriting, and 75% of cases requiring programmers to review every line of AI output. This review and modification process essentially spent back the time supposedly saved.

Even when AI code runs, it likely doesn‚Äôt meet our business expectations. I once had AI optimize Kafka message processing logic. Its solution looked reasonable, but running it revealed improper handling of edge cases like out-of-order and duplicate messages, nearly introducing new bugs. I ended up spending time simplifying the fancy parts it ‚Äúsmartly‚Äù added. Another time, to solve a problem, AI provided a complex multi-threading solution that was overkill and introduced thread safety hazards. AI‚Äôs excessive enthusiasm sometimes backfires, making me spend more time on rework. Ultimately, current AI code reliability is poor, forcing me to stay vigilant and scrutinize with a critical eye, reviewing line by line like code review, fearing it might bury some trap.

Time Drain from Prompt Optimization

Section titled ‚ÄúTime Drain from Prompt Optimization‚Äù

Many think asking AI questions is effortless, but actually getting AI to understand you and provide useful answers requires repeatedly refining prompts. In my experience, this has almost become an art of ‚Äúspeaking human to AI.‚Äù When I had AI help generate product inventory synchronization logic in my project, my first problem description was met with an irrelevant answer; I had to rephrase and add business context, but the second attempt was still unsatisfactory. Going back and forth in deep dialogue with AI for several rounds felt like training a new employee: gradually correcting its misunderstandings and continuously refining requirements. Time spent crafting and optimizing prompts is invisible but very real.

Sometimes, to make AI understand complex scenarios, I‚Äôd even paste relevant code snippets and error messages, which is time-consuming itself. For example, implementing asynchronous refunds in order workflows, I needed it to focus on idempotency and transactionality, and just explaining this business context took a long message. By the time AI gradually ‚Äúgrasped‚Äù my intent, considerable time had passed. These back-and-forth communications essentially produced no new business value, only helped AI figure out the situation. We can say prompt optimization overhead partially offset AI coding‚Äôs acceleration advantages. We think ‚Äúchatting‚Äù with AI is quick, but might actually fall into prolonged debugging conversations, dragging the pace even slower.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

The emergence of AI programming assistants undoubtedly provides developers with new productivity tools. But as revealed by the above personal experiences and research results, current-stage AI is not a silver bullet. It might improve efficiency and reduce grunt work in simple scenarios, but faces complex business logic and large codebases where AI is often willing but unable. Developers must not only spend time waiting and switching focus back and forth, but also cover for AI mistakes and painstakingly train it. These hidden costs accumulate into productivity regression. Of course, we‚Äôre not denying AI tools‚Äô value, but reminding everyone to rationally view their applicability: when proficiency is insufficient or application scenarios don‚Äôt match, AI might actually slow you down.

From a frontline developer‚Äôs perspective, I feel ‚Äúlove-hate.‚Äù AI‚Äôs new approaches and paradigms have benefited me greatly, but when it gets in the way, it‚Äôs truly frustrating. Perhaps as models evolve and our usage skills improve, this 19% disadvantage will transform into real acceleration advantages. But until then, we need more sobriety: don‚Äôt let optimistic AI expectations blind us, and continuously reflect on its cost-effectiveness in actual work. As Greyhound Research analysts said, don‚Äôt mistake developer satisfaction for productivity.

What do you think? What pitfalls have you encountered using AI programming?

  • However, some views suggest the ‚Äústrong dollar‚Äù pattern may not immediately reverse, with disadvantages mainly in capital flows and trade friction escalation, requiring attention to countercyclical shocks from Trump administration tariff policies [10][11][6].

III. Long-term Outlook (1+ Years)

Section titled ‚ÄúIII. Long-term Outlook (1+ Years)‚Äù
  • While the dollar‚Äôs global reserve currency status is difficult to shake, long-term trends including global de-dollarization, rising US fiscal deficits and credit risks, trade protectionism, and multipolar currency systems all weaken the dollar‚Äôs role as the sole safe-haven asset [7][9][8][12].
  • Most institutions believe the dollar is poised to enter a more sustained weak cycle, with estimated decline ranges of 4-10% or more, expecting more frequent volatility heavily influenced by macro and geopolitical events [7][4][9].
  • If the US economy experiences stagflation, policy tightening delays, or global capital flow divergence, dollar assets may continue facing pressure [13][14].

IV. Impact of Tariffs and Rate Cuts on the Dollar

Section titled ‚ÄúIV. Impact of Tariffs and Rate Cuts on the Dollar‚Äù

If tariff negotiations conclude successfully and the Federal Reserve initiates rate cuts, the US Dollar Index will be affected in the following ways:

1. Impact After Tariff Negotiations End

Section titled ‚Äú1. Impact After Tariff Negotiations End‚Äù
  • Inflationary Pressure Relief: If the US successfully reaches tariff agreements with major trading partners (such as the EU, Canada, Mexico, etc.), avoiding new or large-scale tariff implementation, this will directly reduce import cost pressures and help US domestic inflation decline or stabilize [1][2][3].
  • Reduced Market Uncertainty, Weakened Safe-Haven Demand: The near-end of tariff disputes will reduce market risk-aversion sentiment, also decreasing short-term safe-haven buying of the dollar, making the dollar index vulnerable to pressure [4][5].
  • Benefits Exports and Global Risk Appetite Recovery: Lower trade barriers will support US exports and improve global economic confidence, driving rebounds in non-US currencies (such as EUR, JPY, etc.).

2. Impact After Fed Rate Cuts Begin

Section titled ‚Äú2. Impact After Fed Rate Cuts Begin‚Äù
  • Declining Dollar Attractiveness: Fed rate cuts mean lower yields on dollar-denominated assets, weakening the dollar‚Äôs international capital attractiveness, increasing willingness for foreign capital to flow to emerging markets and high-yield currencies, making the dollar index prone to decline [6][7][8][9].
  • Cut Magnitude and Pace Determine Downside Space: If the Fed initiates a relatively aggressive rate-cutting cycle (e.g., 2 or more times per year), dollar depreciation space will increase, with pullback targets potentially below the 102.00 range or lower [7][10].
  • Policy Coordination Creates Trend Inflection Point: Successful tariff negotiations reducing inflation actually give the Fed more sufficient reason to cut rates, with both external factors working together to drive the dollar into a more pronounced medium to long-term weak cycle.

V. Risk and Opportunity Assessment

Section titled ‚ÄúV. Risk and Opportunity Assessment‚Äù

Risks:

  • Federal Reserve monetary policy shift (rate-cutting cycle), declining dollar attractiveness.
  • US high debt, fiscal deficits, and trade deficits, long-term credit erosion.
  • Accelerating global de-dollarization and local currency settlement trends, structurally bearish for the dollar long-term.
  • Geopolitical conflict resolution or non-US economic recovery leading to cyclical capital outflow phenomena.
  • Political risks and sudden events increasing short-term volatility.

Opportunities:

  • During dollar short-term rebounds, swing trading can capture range-bound returns, suitable for flexible investors.
  • The dollar as a safe-haven asset still has short-term allocation value during global crises or geopolitical conflict escalation.
  • Medium to long-term gradual positioning in quality non-US assets (such as Eurozone, yen, Australian dollar, commodity-related assets) may yield excess returns [8][15].
  • Suitable for carry trades, ‚Äúbuy high sell low,‚Äù and cross-currency asset risk diversification.

VI. 2025 Phased ROI Estimation

Section titled ‚ÄúVI. 2025 Phased ROI Estimation‚Äù

According to compiled data, the US Dollar Index peaked near 110 at the beginning of 2025, reaching approximately 97.6 by end-July, representing a year-to-date decline of about -11.3%, meaning US Dollar Index investment ROI for the same period was -11.3% [4][6][1]. This decline represents the worst performance in half a century, far exceeding normal range fluctuations.

Risks

Section titled ‚ÄúRisks‚Äù
  • Repeated Policy Uncertainty: Tariff negotiation pace, agreement details, and subsequent implementation carry reversal risks. If negotiations break down or the Fed returns to hawkishness, dollar adjustment rhythm may be disrupted [1][11][4].
  • Global Factor Disruptions: Sudden geopolitical situations or non-US economies performing unexpectedly weak may cause capital to flow back to the dollar, leading to periodic violent volatility [12][4].

ROI Outlook

Section titled ‚ÄúROI Outlook‚Äù

For dollar-denominated investments, with the dollar index currently near 97, if rate cuts and trade reconciliation jointly drive action, the dollar is expected to experience sustained medium to long-term depreciation. Referencing recent dollar quarterly maximum declines of 5% and annual declines exceeding 11%, if new policies are implemented, the US Dollar Index investment return (ROI) over the next year will likely remain negative (-4% to -10% range), while non-US currencies and assets may achieve positive excess returns [7][8][2].

Conclusion and Recommendations

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion and Recommendations‚Äù

The end of tariff negotiations and Fed rate cuts will form ‚Äúoverlapping headwinds,‚Äù with the dollar showing overall weakness in the short to medium term. Investment strategies should capitalize on dollar rebound opportunities to shift toward diversified non-US asset allocation, manage exchange rate risks, and firmly grasp structural opportunities.

  • Short-term: Range-bound oscillation, data-driven, suitable for swing strategies and cautious high-sell low-buy approaches.
  • Medium-term: Primarily bearish, focus on Fed rate cut implementation timing and global capital flow direction.
  • Long-term: Emphasize dollar index trend risks under multipolar currency framework, gradually increase non-US asset allocation ratios.
  • Close monitoring of the Federal Reserve, US fiscal conditions, trade policies, and global political-economic risks is essential, with strict risk control and dynamic adjustments.

For US Dollar Index-focused investments, be alert to short-term volatility and long-term trend inflection points, reasonably arrange positions and cycles, and do not ignore structural decline risks.

item.title: ChatGPT Agent Review: Smart Reader, But Not Yet a Thinker
item.content:encoded:
ChatGPT Agent first impression: feels like a diligent but not-so-smart intern.

Have You Ever Encountered This Frustration?

Section titled ‚ÄúHave You Ever Encountered This Frustration?‚Äù

Sometimes you come across a seemingly valuable research report or in-depth analysis with an enticing headline, but the content is complex with too much jargon, taking half an hour to read through.

I recently encountered an article titled ‚ÄúHow Long Can the Dollar Keep Falling?‚Äù from Wall Street Insights. The headline was explosive and the content was quite deep, but I really didn‚Äôt have time to read it word by word.

So I had an idea:

Could I use an AI Agent to quickly analyze and summarize it for me?

This led to this experiment‚ÄîI asked ChatGPT Agent to help me read the article.

What Exactly is ChatGPT Agent?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat Exactly is ChatGPT Agent?‚Äù

Simply put, this is the ‚Äúmulti-step execution‚Äù version of ChatGPT.

Instead of just throwing a prompt and getting back one response, it can make multiple tool calls and complete complex tasks in multiple steps, such as reading an article, calling search functions, extracting viewpoints, doing analysis, etc.

It sounds impressive, and I thought it could help me ‚Äúdelegate‚Äù those information-heavy article analysis tasks.

The result?

14 Minutes Later: Usable But Not Practical

Section titled ‚Äú14 Minutes Later: Usable But Not Practical‚Äù

I sent the content of ‚ÄúHow Long Can the Dollar Keep Falling?‚Äù to the Agent and asked:

Help me extract the article‚Äôs viewpoints, provide key logic, and include investment-related reference suggestions.

It did work very diligently,

After waiting 14 minutes, it returned a structured analysis,

Roughly divided into:

  • Short-term and long-term logic for USD weakness
  • Economic data and viewpoints cited by the author
  • Market disagreements on future USD trends
  • Linkage mechanisms between exchange rates and monetary policy

At first glance, the content seemed comprehensive, with summary statements that looked quite professional.

But the biggest problem was: too generic, too textbook-like, lacking ‚Äúpractical operational value‚Äù.

For example, I wanted to know:

  • Has it already hit bottom? Are there any signals worth watching?
  • What implications does this have for people holding US bonds, QDII, or US stocks?

The Agent couldn‚Äôt answer these questions. It was just restating the article content, without ‚Äújumping out‚Äù to integrate broader context.

Like a Diligent But Not-So-Smart Intern

Section titled ‚ÄúLike a Diligent But Not-So-Smart Intern‚Äù

The whole process made me feel like it was a diligent intern who read through the material and took notes:

  • Can summarize, but doesn‚Äôt dare to judge;
  • Can restate, but can‚Äôt extract insights;
  • Will say ‚Äúthe article mentions,‚Äù but won‚Äôt say ‚Äúthis means you might consider xxx.‚Äù

Not to mention combining it with my own investment portfolio or current exchange rate data to provide practical advice.

To summarize: the content is reference-worthy, but not very practical.

Can It Still Be Useful? When Is It Most Suitable?

Section titled ‚ÄúCan It Still Be Useful? When Is It Most Suitable?‚Äù

Although I was a bit disappointed this time, I think ChatGPT Agent is still useful.

It‚Äôs suitable for these scenarios:

  • Quick preview when too lazy to read the full text: Like 10 minutes before a meeting, quickly catching the key points
  • Help organize structure: It‚Äôs faster than me at listing paragraph logic and key points, suitable as a foundation for presentation scripts
  • Information overload relief tool: Having it help me read 5 research reports and extract common points‚Äîthis kind of manual labor it excels at

But expecting it to help me make judgments, make decisions, or formulate investment strategies‚Äîit‚Äôs still far from that.

Perhaps we need to continue deeper interaction with ChatGPT Agent, providing more contextual information to make it more practical.

AI Isn‚Äôt a Crystal Ball, It‚Äôs More Like an Accelerator

Section titled ‚ÄúAI Isn‚Äôt a Crystal Ball, It‚Äôs More Like an Accelerator‚Äù

The biggest takeaway from this trial:

AI isn‚Äôt someone who thinks for you; it‚Äôs an accelerator that helps you quickly ‚Äútake over repetitive tasks‚Äù.

Judgment, understanding, connecting to reality, combining experience‚Äîthese are still things humans need to do.

In the future, I‚Äôll continue trying to use ChatGPT Agent for information screening, knowledge archiving, document generation and other tasks, rather than expecting it to ‚Äúthink for me‚Äù right from the start.

Have You Also Used ChatGPT Agent?

Section titled ‚ÄúHave You Also Used ChatGPT Agent?‚Äù

Have you tried using ChatGPT Agent for any tasks? How was the effect?

Share in the comments, let‚Äôs explore together where AI can truly help.

Core Competencies & Development Directions for Developers in the AI Era

Section titled ‚ÄúCore Competencies & Development Directions for Developers in the AI Era‚Äù

Even with powerful AI Coding tools, developers still possess irreplaceable core value.

Section titled ‚Äú1. From ‚ÄúCode Monkey‚Äù to ‚ÄúEngineering Lead‚Äù‚Äù

AI tools dramatically reduce coding execution costs. The future values those who can organize teams to achieve goals and design system architecture rather than hand-write every line of code.

Ability to think from business and product angles, understanding users and objectives, guides AI tools to create truly usable solutions.
